Description: # Objective Currently in `bevy_render` the renderer initialization (e.g. creating a surface, registering rendering systems) is very intertwined with setting up the extraction logic itself (e.g. how is data moved between the worlds, how are they kept in sync). This makes it harder to understand both things, and also makes it very hard to test the extraction logic, as you don't want to start the renderer in unit test. In the future this functionality might even be useful for the ECS outside `bevy_render`, e.g. for custom renderers that want to use a render world, or for multi world setups. ## Solution This PR splits out creation of the render subapp plus the extraction logic itself into `ExtractPlugin`, and uses the new found flexibility to finally add a test for it. instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: fix: improve semantic clarity for run condition combinators

Description: # Objective We include several run condition combinators, such as `and`, `or`, etc., which short-circuit depending on the output of the first condition in the combinator. This is incredibly error-prone due to the subtle way that short-circuiting interacts with change detection -- rather than reacting to changes frame-by-frame, the second condition in short-circuiting combinator will react to _the last time that the first condition did not short circuit_. This can easily lead to confusing bugs if the user does not expect this, and I suspect that most users will not expect this. For this reason, when combining multiple run conditions added via `.run_if()`, all run conditions are intentionally eagerly evaluated. ## Solution Add new run condition combinators `and_then`, `and_eager`, `or_else`,
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: fix: improve semantic clarity for run condition combinators

Title: Make Gizmos::rect_2d and primitive_2d draw the joint of the first corner of closed shapes

Description: Make `Gizmos::rect_2d` and `primitive_2d` draw the joint of the first corner of closed shapes # Objective - `Gizmos::rect_2d` and `primitive_2d` do not draw the line joint between the first and last segments. This looks odd when the line joint is not `GizmoLineJoint::None`. (This affects `Triangle2d`, `Rhombus`, `Rectangle`, `Polygon`, and `RegularPolygon`.) - Fixes #22081. ## Solution - `Gizmos::rect_2d` and `primitive_2d` draw using `Gizmos::linestrip_2d`, which doesn't draw a closed shape. - In order to make `linestrip_2d` to draw a joint at a corner, that corner has to be in the points list with a predecessor and a successor. - There is no predecessor for the first element in the list, and no successor when it is repeated as the last. - Appending the second point to the list is enough
output:
Severity: medium
Component: graphics
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Make Gizmos::rect_2d and primitive_2d draw the joint of the first corner of closed shapes

Title: enable tracy subscriber layer on android

Description: # Objective I really need tracing on android right now as I'm attempting to profile bevy running on a quest 3. ## Solution I saw [this issue](https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/issues/21612) already opened about it around 2 weeks ago, and I was able to use it to figure out how to enable tracy to run on android. However I did not enable it for IOS and made sure to retain the same behavior for other flags such as chrome style profiling. ## Testing I've tested that the engine still builds on both windows and to android. Additionally the flame graph will now show complete frames of info, instead of one single mono-frame with 4 different render events. Android also requires: `android.permission.INTERNET` and possibly `android.permission.NEARBY_WIFI_DEVICES` to be able to host the debug server.

Title: Fix multithreaded access to additional crash files

Description: `GetScenarioInfo` can be called from a `JobPool` in `FileIndex::Build`, resulting in multiple threads trying to access the `_uploadFiles` map for breakpad. This commit adds a mutex guard for `_uploadFiles` and provides unique names for the entries. The crash handler itself does not verify mutex state, possibly causing data races, but I don't think it's safe to access it at this point and we have to make do with whatever state is present at this point. This fixes my observation and concern in https://github.com/OpenRCT2/OpenRCT2/issues/25260#issuecomment-3332965656

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: Fix dragging-over panic

Description: # Objective Problems: * If a drag starts over a hovered entity, `picking_events` doesn't add the hovered entity to the `dragging_over` map in `PointerButtonState`. This causes a panic when the pointer is moved and `picking_events` tries to update the non-existant `dragging_over` state for the hovered entity. * `DragEnter` isn't dispatched on `DragStart`. This doesn't seem ideal. The drag isn't crossing a geometric boundary, but it is causing the dragged over entities to enter into a dragged over state. Fixes #21998 ## Solution * Update the `dragging_state` for all hovered entities every frame, before handling any `PointerInput`s. * Reworked the `DragEnter` dispatch logic. `DragEnter` now also fires when a drag starts over an already hovered entity. ## Testing The examples using drag events
output:
Severity: critical
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Fix dragging-over panic

Title: Add extra padding to font atlases

Description: # Objective Text rendered with Text2d sometimes shows visual artifacts: https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/885021580353237032/1465484728512675902/screenshot-2026-01-26-at-15.08.45.png?ex=69794682&is=6977f502&hm=e22ced378cafba3d97d77d322c41405e01e1027cdaf8108ff300c0f3f174c0f8& Fixes #22716 ## Solution This is probably because the font atlases are too tightly packed for non-pixel aligned text. Add an extra pixel of padding to the font atlases. # Adding extra padding is enough to remove the artifacts as reported, but longer term: 1. We should look into better font rendering for Text2d that produces high quality text regardless of scaling and sub pixel coords. 2. The texture atlas builder should support extrusion.

Title: Remove MapSector, take 2

Description: Retry of #10656, should make more sense after #12321 This completely removes MapSector and stores all blocks directly on the Map (as unordered_map<v3s16, unique_ptr<MapBlock>>, similar to MapSector + Map before). It also gets rid of the last seen block caches we had in Map and MapSector. They did not seem to do much, but I am happy to bring a cache back. This makes the code cleaner. It's somewhat hard to say whether the one call to to the new `Map::getBlockNoCreateNoEx` takes more time than `MapSector::getBlockNoCreateNoEx` + `Map::getSectorNoGenerateNoLock`. Maybe a little bit, but it seems within the noise. I could use some help testing. - Goal of the PR See above, code cleanliness - How does the PR work? See above. - Does it resolve any reported issue? input:
Title: Fix wrong termination for asset hash reads.

Description: # Objective - #21925 changed the hash computation to read the file piece by piece. Unfortunately, the termination condition is wrong for this loop. We should only exit once the reader has no more bytes (`bytes_read == 0`), otherwise, the reader might partially fill the buffer, and that may be interpretted as an EOF. - I originally did this check, but something was failing due to never terminating the read. Unclear what happened, maybe I got mixed up! ## Solution - Check if there are no bytes left rather than if the buffer is partially filled. ## Testing - Ran the asset tests with --all-features - Ran the `asset_processor` example and it seems to work!
output:
Severity: low
Component: save
Reproducibility: rare
Summary: Fix wrong termination for asset hash reads.

Description: In one of the strangest goose-chases I've had debugging SCons, it turns out that `.inc` is *not* automatically recognized as a valid header dependency with the ninja backend. So while technically strictly a stylistic change, this actually made all the difference in allowing the minimal template to compile on GHA when using ninja. PR as two commits to add this change to `.git-blame-ignore-revs` ### [Before:](https://github.com/Repiteo/godot/actions/runs/21733555572/job/62693495648) ``` ... [305/1006] Compiling core/config/engine.linuxbsd.template_release.x86_64.o FAILED: [code=1] core/config/engine.linuxbsd.template_release.x86_64.o export PATH='/opt/hostedtoolcache/Python/3.14.2/x64/bin:/opt/hostedtoolcache/Python/3.14.2/x64:/snap/bin:/home/runner/.local/bin:/opt/pipx_bin:/home/runner/.car
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui

Summary: Style: Convert `*.gen.inc` to `*.gen.h` for ninja

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: Don't close Luanti when escape is pressed

Description: I think this is an antifeature and it's trivial to remove. Rationale: * It's easy to accidentally close Luanti when you're escaping some dialogs via <kbd>Esc</kbd>. * I don't expect <kbd>Esc</kbd> to close an application completely. I struggle to find another serious example of this. * People can still use their platform-specific WM keybinds (e.g. <kbd>Alt</kbd> <kbd>F4</kbd>). Why have a redundant Luanti-specific one? See also: https://ux.stackexchange.com/questions/103220/should-escape-immediately-close-an-application This PR is ready for discussion.
output:
Severity: low
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Don't close Luanti when escape is pressed

input: Title: Parallel GPU buffer writes Description: # Objective - After a series of optimizations making render and postupdate more parallel, `write_batched_instance_buffers` was regularly one of the largest spans with very low thread use, sitting at 4ms in 1 4ms frame. This makes it an ideal target to improve throughput. Note this screenshot doesn't include some visibility system optimizations: ## Solution - Spawn tasks for writing buffers to the GPU. This is especially helpful for `current_input_buffer` and `previous_input_buffer`, which take about the same time and are the longest buffer writes - moving these to tasks effectively halves the time spent in the system.

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: Release the asset infos lock before acquiring the file transaction lock.

Description: # Objective - Fix the first flake related to #22001. - We had a double lock problem. We would first lock `asset_infos`, then lock one of the assets within `asset_infos` **and then dropped the `asset_infos` lock**. This means however that if a process needs to access `asset_infos` (which is necessary for loading nested assets during processing), we'll have one thread trying to lock 1) asset_infos, 2) per-asset lock, and we'll have another thread trying to lock 1) per-asset lock (we've already dropped the asset_infos lock), 2) asset_infos. A classic deadlock! ## Solution - Before locking the per-asset lock, we clone the `Arc<RwLock>` out of the `asset_infos`, drop the `asset_infos`, and only then lock the per-asset lock. This ensures that we never hang on the `asset_infos` lock when just try
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Release the asset infos lock before acquiring the file transaction lock.

Title: [Take 2] Prevent MapBlocks in generation from being unloaded

Description: (Forwarded from repetitivestrain on IRC) (Continues after #16335 after I accidentally push-deleted it) ### Goal of the PR Prevent issues arising from partial generation of MapChunks, which are liable to be regenerated completely when ungenerated MapBlocks within are encountered. A two-stage Lua map generator under development is not able to maintain determinism or in general respond to situations where MapChunks are generated repetitiously. ### How does the PR work? By obtaining a reference to MapBlocks in generation (for which temporary and empty MapBlocks are created, which are subject to the same active block management as all others), so that they may not be unloaded before the emerge process is complete. ### Does it resolve any reported issue? https://github.com/luanti-org/luanti/issu
output:
Severity: medium
Component: network
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: [Take 2] Prevent MapBlocks in generation from being unloaded

Title: relax return value of `World::resource_scope`

Description: # Objective Follow-up to #22290 Currently, when calling `resource_scope` or `try_resource_scope`, the function will panic or return `None`, respectively, if `World::clear_resources` is called from within the scope. This behavior was intentionally preserved in #22290 to reduce user-facing changes, however the behavior is not necessary, as, at the point where it becomes relevant, the user-provided scope closure has already completed successfully. Since we explicitly support methods such as `clear_resources`, we should treat them as valid to call, and avoid causing unnecessary knock-on errors. ## Testing A test added in #22290 was updated to reflect the new behavior.

Title: fix enum reflection based partial_cmp, disallow compare different variant names.

Description: # Objective Fix https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/issues/22586 The problem is in https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/pull/22452 I used `variant_index` to compare two enum values. Because I want to maintain: * if you have `a,b: A` and tries call `a.reflect_partial_cmp(b)`, the result should align with the version derived on `A`. But appearently for dynamic types and also `a: A; b: B` different types, the behaviour is a bit chaotic. (see https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/issues/22586) ## Solution Don't compare by `variant_index` anymore. It's a different tradeoff, but I think it's a more sensible one. ## Testing Modified unit tests

Severity: medium
Component: other
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: fix enum reflection based partial_cmp, disallow compare different variant names.

Title: Mapgen doesn't fix / spread light when blitting back

Description: ### Info ``` Luanti 5.15.0-dev-9c37b46e1 (Linux) ``` ### Summary You can set nodes into blocks that aren't generated yet. This can affect the lighting situation in the resulting block. E.g. one can create an enclosed space. Then when the mapgen blits back its nodes (and when these nodes are bright in the vmanip (this only happens if the block read by mapgen didn't yet contain the placed structure (race condition))), the resulting nodes can stay bright even though they are in an enclosed space. Title: Replace PathBuf-based resolution in AssetPath::resolve with URL-like segment resolver

Description: # Objective Replace `PathBuf`-based path resolution in `AssetPath::resolve` / `resolve_embed` with a deterministic, URL-like algorithm that operates on asset-path segments (string slices), avoiding platform-specific filesystem semantics (e.g. Windows drive letters). This is a follow-up to concerns raised in review of #22416 ## Context `AssetPath` is not a filesystem path; it is closer to a URL-like path used by the asset framework. Today, `AssetPath::resolve` uses `PathBuf` internally for normalization / joining. `PathBuf` applies platform-specific parsing and normalization rules that are not intended for Bevy asset paths and could be a source of subtle bugs. ## Proposed change - Implement an internal resolver that: - treats `/` as the only separator - resolves `.` and `..` via predictable

Summary: Replace PathBuf-based resolution in AssetPath::resolve with URL-like segment resolver

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: Implement parallax-corrected cubemaps (PCCMs) for reflection probes.

Description: Bevy doesn't currently ever apply parallax correction to cubemaps, so reflections are rendered as though the environment were infinitely far away. This is often acceptable for outdoor scenes in which the environment is very distant, but for indoor scenes and dense environments this is undesirable. The standard solution for this problem is *parallax correction*, in which each reflection probe is augmented with a bounding box, and a raytrace is performed against the bounding box in order to determine the proper direction for sampling the cubemap. This commit implements parallax correction in Bevy for light probes in an opt-out manner. (You may add the `NoParallaxCorrection` component to a `LightProbe` with an `EnvironmentMapLight` in order to opt out of it.) The bounding box used for paralla
output:
Severity: low
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Implement parallax-corrected cubemaps (PCCMs) for reflection probes.

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: `.jpeg` is not a recognized file extension + bad error messages

Description: We support JPG images, but we do not support the `.jpeg` file extension: We consider only file names that end in `.jpg` (see e.g. `Server::addMediaFile`). To someone who is not familiar with the engine, this is subtle and confusing. (I noticed this at FOSDEM, during the workshop, when kids were trying to use `.jpeg` files from the internet in their mods.) I see two ways we can fix the `.jpeg` problem: 1. Just allow `.jpeg`. 2. Communicate clearly with big fat warning or error messages when we do find `.jpeg` images in media folders that we don't load them, and suggest they be renamed to `.jpeg` (yes, technically an attentive reader of `lua_api.md` could figure this out, but we want the engine to be friendly to use out of the box). Additionally, the error message that is produced is unhelpf
output:
Severity: medium
Component: network
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: `.jpeg` is not a recognized file extension + bad error messages

Title: Add PlayStation 5 DualSense controller support

Description: ## Summary Add PlayStation 5 DualSense controller support Implements a complete button and axis layout for the PS5 DualSense controller, matching Minecraft console-style controls: - **Analog sticks:** Movement (left) and camera control (right) - **Face buttons:** Jump (X), Sneak (Circle), Camera mode (Square), Drop item (Triangle) - **Triggers:** L2/R2 mapped as analog axes for dig/place actions - **Bumpers:** L1/R1 for hotbar navigation - **Stick clicks:** L3 for sprint, R3 for zoom - **D-pad:** Fly mode, autoforward, minimap, fast movement - **Touchpad click:** Opens inventory - **Options button:** Pause menu The layout is automatically detected when a controller named "DualSense" is connected, or can be manually selected with `joystick_type = ps5`. **Note:** L2/R2 triggers use negative

Summary: Add PlayStation 5 DualSense controller support

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: Camera ambiguity warnings shouldn't run every frame

Description: ## What problem does this solve or what need does it fill? Currently when two cameras exist on the same render layer, without explicit ordering, warnings will be printed to the console on every frame. While important to let users know about, this does make it hard for users to see their own logs, including logs that they may be using to debug the issue. ## What solution would you like? I'm not certain `warn_once` would work as it might confuse users into thinking that issue has been solved. Perhaps logging once per second? ## What alternative(s) have you considered? Leave it as is. This is already an uncommon issue and the only real case where the solution isn't easy is when importing scenes that have cameras which will be solved when the editor is released.
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: rare
Summary: Camera ambiguity warnings shouldn't run every frame

Title: Fix non-srgb `RenderTarget::Image`

Description: # Objective Fixes https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/pull/22031#issuecomment-3640036590. Fixes #15201. #22031 makes `ViewTarget::out_texture_format` to return the underlying texture’s format, which causes some issues: 1. `ExtractedWindow::swap_chain_texture_view` always uses srgb view. But the underlying swap chain texture in WebGPU can be Bgra8unorm, leading to format mismatch between the render pipeline and the render pass. 2. input:
Title: Script API proposal: Delay server / client start via a step callback

Description: ### Problem TL;DR: There are things that you want to do asynchronously at server or client start. And the server shouldn't start or the client shouldn't join before this asynchronous work is done. In SSCSM, we will likely have some sort of channel with which SSCSM and SSM (server side modding) can communicate. When the client joins, one will like to have the guarantee that the mod's channels are initialized. The initialization however will probably be asynchronous, as waiting for each channel separately would be a waste of time. Also, after initialization, mods will want to do communication between SSM and SSCSM, also asynchronously. The client should not join before this is done. Similarly, in SSM, expensive work during server start could be outsourced to a separate thread, to make the se
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Script API proposal: Delay server / client start via a step callback

Title: Fix dragging bug in drag_to_scroll example

Description: # Objective Fixes #21675. The issue was that the position the drag started on was never saved so new drags always forced the grid to its initial position. The original entity hierarchy consists of a `ScrollableNode`, with a child node (grid parent), which itself has a bunch of nodes as children (grid tiles). Only the grid node has a `Pickable` component. There are a few issues in the original code: * Since grid tiles have `should_block_lower = false` and `is_hoverable = true`, they will allow drag events to propagate to the grid parent. Since the grid parent does not have `Pickable`, it blocks further propagation but does ding a scroll event. This creates two scroll events observed by the `ScrollableNode`. * However, neither of these are the same entity as the `ScrollableNode`, so both eve
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: always
Summary: Fix dragging bug in drag_to_scroll example

Title: `TextPipeline::update_buffer` return with early error on degenerate scale factor

Description: # Objective `TextPipeline::update_buffer` checks per text section if the scale factor is <= 0 but if the scale factor is degenerate none of the text sections will be rendered. It would make more sense to perform the check once, at the start of the function, and return with an early error if it fails. ## Solution Add a new variant to `TextError` called `DegenerateScaleFactor`. At the start of the `update_buffer` function, return with an early `DegenerateScaleFactor` error if the scale factor is <= 0.

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: bevy_asset: support upgrading Reader to SeekableReader

Description: # Objective #22104 added `AsyncSeek` support, but it has some downsides: - It is very "loose": it relies on `AssetLoader` to "attest" that it needs the seek feature. However, AssetLoaders both have access to the `AsyncSeek` API no matter what (it is a supertrait of Reader), and AssetReaders provide `AsyncSeek` behavior even if it isn't requested. In practice this is likely to create situations where AssetLoaders don't request `AsyncSeek` and just rely on it being provided by default, causing unexpected incompatibilities when AssetLoader consumers try to use other AssetReaders that don't support AsyncSeek. - It encourages building "fallback" behavior into the AssetReader in cases where AsyncSeek cannot be supported directly (ex: read the while contents into a Vec). From the perspective of l
output:

Summary: bevy_asset: support upgrading Reader to SeekableReader

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: Fix the `NodePath` hash function to not yield the same value for similar paths

Description: - Should fix #115407 xor-ing consecutive elements is not a valid hashing strategy. In the current implementation, `A/B` results in the same hash as `B/A`. The new implementation simply hashes the full path and subpath separately, then combines them using a valid hashing strategy. Since the resulting hash is well-formed, the `is_absolute` can be used to flip bits, since the bit-flipped version of a well distributed hash is still a well distributed hash. It's probably not the best strategy ever, but it should be good enough. The new implementation is more expensive to compute the hash for a completely new `NodePath` than before, but it utilizes the concatenated caches, so it will speed up other operations (and itself be cheap to compute if the caches already exist).
output:
Severity: low
Component: other
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Fix the `NodePath` hash function to not yield the same value for similar paths

Title: Fix race conditions in DirAccessWindows leading to segfaults

Description: <!-- Please target the `master` branch in priority. Relevant fixes are cherry-picked for stable branches as needed by maintainers. To speed up the contribution process and avoid CI errors, please set up pre-commit hooks locally: https://contributing.godotengine.org/en/latest/engine/guidelines/code_style.html --> In the constructor for `DirAccessWindows()`, we use `GetCurrentDirectoryW()` without engaging the global lock function. This is a problem if you are instancing `DirAccess` objects on multiple threads, since we call `change_dir()` right after. `change_dir()` calls `SetCurrentDirectoryW()`, which changes the whole process's current dir. output:

This can be fixed by either using a separator or length prefix. I recommend length prefix, because with a separator you'd need to make sure it doesn't appear in names. Description: Fixes #91689 This PR fixes problems and inconsistencies with getters or setters defined by separate functions, on typed properties. The getter side of this is more involved. To ensure the getter function result is automatically converted to the property type, without affecting the function itself (as it may have other uses), the compiler now generates new wrapper function for each such getter that needs a conversion. The wrapper just calls the assigned function and converts the results before returning it. The analyzer checks for getter functions that need to have their results converted, marks this using the new `VariableNode::use_getter_conversion` field. Title: Fix crash when passing `null` return pointer to GDExtension call methods

Description: Added null checking for the return argument in the following methods: - `gdextension_variant_call` - `gdextension_variant_call_static` - `gdextension_object_call_script_method` - `gdextension_object_method_bind_call` When the return pointer is `null`, these functions now ignore it. This allows callers to discard return values when calling void-returning methods or when the return value is not needed. My main motivation for this change is that in the C# bindings we pass a `null` pointer when calling void-returning methods, I don't really care about discarding the return for non-void-returning methods. Title: Tilemap chunk update has ambiguous scheduling

Description: TilemapChunks are updated once per frame in [update](https://docs.rs/bevy_sprite_render/0.17.3/src/bevy_sprite_render/tilemap_chunk/mod.rs.html#38), however the system is not in any system sets not is it public so it can't be scheduled around in user code. Reported on discord by user weykent https://discord.com/channels/691052431525675048/691052431974465548/1448481798211502220. instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input: Title: Prevent DoF effect disappearing at small `focus_distances` Description: # Objective - In the `depth_of_field` example, setting `focal_distance` to a small value (<= 0.02) causes the DoF effect to disappear unexpectedly. - I believe that a small focal_distance makes `(focus - f)` zero or negative. This leads to a non-positive candidate_coc, which is then clamped to 0.0, effectively disabling the DoF effect. - Although the formula is physically accurate, we cannot assume users have a deep understanding of the depth of field effect. This will make them confused. ## Solution - Use `max(focus - f, EPSILON)` to ensure the denominator is always positive. - Now, the effect looks correct.
output:
Severity: medium
Component: graphics
Reproducibility: always
Summary: Prevent DoF effect disappearing at small `focus_distances`

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: LSP: Handle clients that do not support `CompletionContext`

Description: Fixes the error spam from https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/115631 The whole completion context member is not mandatory and clients do not need to implement it. Previously we would implicitly fallback through invalid dictionary lookups. Since this now throws errors this PR adds an explicit fallback. The default value of `triggerKind` has been changed to `Invoked` this makes sense, because for `TriggerCharacter` the `triggerCharacter` member should contain the character, but it defaults to an empty string. Quick link to the relevant specification: https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/lsp/3.17/specification/#completionTriggerKind
output:
Severity: high
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: LSP: Handle clients that do not support `CompletionContext`

Title: Fix AABB calculation in Mesh::take_gpu_data

Description: # Objective - Fixes #22169 ## Solution - `Mesh::take_gpu_data` was calling `Aabb3d::new` and passing it min and max, but the constructor expected center and half size. This caused a panic for meshes where the vertices are all negative on any of the axes. And also means the aabb is incorrect, maybe causing issues like incorrect frustum culling? After a bit of discussion on Discord, the `new` constructor expecting center & half extents was deemed footgunny. So this PR renames `Aabb3d::new` to `Aabb::from_half_size`, and adds a new constructor `Aabb::from_min_max`. `Mesh::take_gpu_data` now calls `from_min_max`, fixing the AABB calculation bug. ## Testing - I hit this bug with a model where all the vertices were negative in one dimension (so the max is all negative, and when it was wrongly pa
output:
Severity: medium
Component: save
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Fix AABB calculation in Mesh::take_gpu_data

Title: Gate Render Diagnostics for MacOS

Description: # Objective Help out with #22257 ## Solution There is an open question about whether render diagnostics might be causing the flickering for MacOS, so this gates any render diagnostic code such that MacOS targets do not include them. They supposedly do not work on MacOS anyway, so this shouldn’t affect anything. (Should I also add ios as a `not` target?) ## Testing Unfortunately, I’m not affected by the bug, but hopefully other people can test this. If this actually solves the flickering problem, I can take this out of draft. To try to see if this solves the issue, run `cargo run --example bloom_3d --features=trace_tracy` with many instances and also several times, and see if you can get flickering. This should be done particularly if you are on MacOS, and please note which OS you are using

Title: UI scrollbars clipping fix

Description: # Objective #### Fix two problems 1. Scrollbars are placed in the padding region of the node, not the content region. The content insets returned by `ComputedNode::content_inset` should account for the sizes of the scrollbars. 3. In `update_clipping_system` the clipping rect calculations are incorrect, `scrollbar_size` should only be added to the `right` and `bottom` when `visual_area` is set to `ContentBox`. For `BorderBox` and `PaddingBox`, the scrollbars are inside the clipping rect. ## Solution 1. Add the scrollbar size to the `right` and `bottom` insets returned by `ComputedNode::content_inset`. 2. Since `content_inset` now includes `scrollbar size`, remove the subtraction from `clip_rect.max` in `update_clipping_system`. ## Testing Look at: ``` cargo run --example scrollbars --featur
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: UI scrollbars clipping fix

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: Don't render meshes that have prepass disabled to the prepass, even if they have shadows enabled.

Description: Currently, the `specialize_prepass_material_meshes` function adds meshes to the prepass unless both `prepass_enabled` *and* `shadows_enabled` are false for that material. This seems incorrect, as (1) the flags are separate for a reason and (2) meshes are added to the shadow pass not in `specialize_prepass_material_meshes` but in `specialize_shadows`. This patch changes `specialize_prepass_material_meshes` to skip adding meshes to the prepass if `prepass_enabled` is false, even if `shadows_enabled` is true.
output:

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: Fix incorrect `TypeId` retrieval in reflect component clone

Description: # Objective Fix incorrect `TypeId` retrieval in `ComponentCloneCtx::write_target_component_reflect()`. When cloning reflected components, the code incorrectly called `.type_id()` on a `Box<dyn Reflect>`, which returns the container's `TypeId` rather than the underlying concrete type's `TypeId`. For example: ```rust let boxed: Box<dyn Reflect> = Box::new(String::from("test")); // Correct: dereferencing gets the concrete type's TypeId assert_eq!((*boxed).type_id(), TypeId::of::<String>()); // Wrong: calling on Box returns something else assert_ne!(boxed.type_id(), TypeId::of::<String>()); ``` See Rust documentation: <https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/any/index.html#smart-pointers-and-dyn-any>. ## Solution Dereference the `Box<dyn Reflect>` before calling `.type_id()` to obtain the concrete type'
output:
Severity: medium
Component: save
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Fix incorrect `TypeId` retrieval in reflect component clone

Title: Fix binding in generated environment map downsampling pipeline

Description: # Objective When Bevy splits mip generation for environment maps into two passes due to limits, the second pass binds a view to the the original texture when it's supposed to be the 6th mip level of an intermediate one. This causes an error on WebGPU in browsers if that original texture doesn't already have mipmaps. This affects the atmosphere example on WebGPU, but there are other issues there too so it still won't work after this. ## Solution Create texture view from the texture in the `IntermediateTextures` component instead of in `RenderEnvironmentMap` ## Testing <details> <summary>Example that doesn't work on WebGPU before this (replace square.png with any power of 2 square image that doesn't store mipmaps)</summary> ```rust use bevy::prelude::*; fn main() { App::new() .add_plugins(De

Title: 0.18: Potential panic when accessing Meshes due to retained render world only assets

Description: ## Bevy version and features main after #21732 ## What you did Run `mesh_picking` example with a RENDER_WORLD-only mesh and try picking it. ## What went wrong It panics and exits. This is a regression because before #21732 `mesh_picking` would never access render world only meshes. ## Additional information This is a breaking change that requires a migration guide, especially for physics crates that need to iterate over Meshes. They can easily panic by accidentally accessing a render world only mesh. The migration path is to always use the try_xxx methods instead of the original ones that could panic, but this may this is unintuitive and error-prone. Personally, I would suggest we revert it and redo it in 0.19 if this isn’t improved in 0.18, given that the side effects of #21732 currently

input:
Title: Fix motion blur and dof on WebGL2 and WebGPU

Description: # Objective Motion blur and DOF are not supported on webgl2 because they need read depth and shadow sampler `texture_depth_2d` can't be sampled on webgl2. Also, depth prepass is not supported on webgl2 because `copy_texture_to_texture` doesn't work for depth texture. ## Solution Use `ViewDepthTexture` intead of `ViewPrepassTextures.depth` and bind depth texture as `texture_2d<f32>`. ## Testing Tested `motion_blur` and `depth_of_field` examples on webgl2.
output:
Severity: high
Component: graphics
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Fix motion blur and dof on WebGL2 and WebGPU

Title: Add new hotbar_slot_selected lua callback

Description: ## Goal of the PR The goal here is to allow a way for items in the hotbar to be activated the same way hotbar spells/skills are activated in some other games - via a single key press / screen tap on mobile. Currently this is only possible by first selecting an item and then having to use/place that item, thus requiring a key press (or scroll) and then a mouse click - or alternatively two taps on mobile. This PR aims to allow a way to only activate an item in the hotbar via single-key press (or screen tap on mobile). This would allow, as an example, games to be written where hotbar items can be treated as skills or spells to be activated, rather than items to be used. Title: Run individual `SystemSet`s in `Schedule`s

Description: ## Objective - Part of #20115 - Indirectly contributes to #16432 - Indirectly contributes to #9792 - Closes #12717 Bevy users occasionally ask for the ability to run specific `SystemSet`s in a `Schedule`, commonly for unit testing behaviors. Beyond that, this functionality brings us closer to turning our `Update`, `PostUpdate`, etc *schedules* into *system sets* by giving system sets a power that previously only schedules had: the ability to be executed. ## Solution - Added a new parameter to `SystemExecutor::run`: `subgraph: Option<SystemSetKey>` - If `Some`, the provided `SystemSetKey` is used to fetch a bitset of the systems that are part of the set (including transitively), which is used to filter the `SystemExecutor` to execute only those systems. - If `None`, the `SystemExecutor` fun
output:

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: MeshMaterial2d doesn't require Visibility and Transform

Description: ## What problem does this solve or what need does it fill? In a recent discord discussion, a newcomer created a simple hierarchy composed of Sprites and MeshMaterial2d. Whereas Sprite entities would have a Visibility component thanks to Sprite's required components, the MeshMaterial2d did not, leading to a non-obvious bug. ## What solution would you like? I think it would be good for MeshMaterial2d to require Visibility, as I can't think of a scenario where such an entity would not be eventually rendered to the screen, in the same way that Sprite requires it. In the same spirit, I think it should also require Transform, which is also required for actual rendering to take place. I believe that scenarios where this would be a downside are very few, and could simply insert Visibility::Hidden
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: always
Summary: MeshMaterial2d doesn't require Visibility and Transform

Title: Delete `InstrumentedAssetLoader` and `InstrumentedAssetProcessor`, but keep the instrumentation.

Description: # Objective - In #12988, we added tracing spans to asset loading and processing, by creating wrapper structs `InstrumentedAssetLoader` and `InstrumentedAssetProcessor`. - Unfortunately, this causes an issue where `ErasedAssetLoader::{default_meta, type_path}` and `ErasedProcessor::default_meta` can return the wrong type path when using the `trace` feature, and this type path could be written into a meta file, which will be rendered unloadable/unprocessable. - Note even though the loader/processor's type use to have the instrumentation wrapper, when registering the loader/processor, we would actually register the loader/processor under the original type names. So you could still load non-`trace` written meta files, but `trace` written meta files would fail to load whether `trace` was enable
output:
Severity: high
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Delete `InstrumentedAssetLoader` and `InstrumentedAssetProcessor`, but keep the instrumentation.

input:
Title: Deprecate function support in `core.[de]serialize`

Description: This deprecates support for dumping functions in `core.serialize`. Consequently, support for loading (or silently stripping) functions in `core.deserialize` is also deprecated. There are a plethora of reasons for this: 1. This just dumps bytecode, which is not portable. 2. If mod security is enabled, loading bytecode will cause an error. 3. Dumping functions is very restricted. Most functions won't work correctly after being dumped because upvalues are not preserved. Only pure functions that only use the environment have a chance to work. 4. Even more, for security reasons, we change the environment to a fresh, essentially empty one, so practically no function will really work, unless environments are somehow restored. 5. General security-ish reasons of a wanted data-code separation; espec
output:
Severity: critical
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Deprecate function support in `core.[de]serialize`

Title: [no squash] Fix handling of skinned meshes for nodes

Description: Supersedes #16089. - Rigidly animated models (e.g. the gltf frog node) were not working correctly, since cloning the mesh ignored the transformation matrices. Note that scaling the mesh needs to occur *after* transforming the vertices. - Visual scale did not apply to skinned models, as resetting the animation overwrote scaled vertex data with static positions & normals. For backwards compatibility, we only apply a 10x scale to static (.obj) models. ## How to test The gltf frog node should look correct. (While on latest master, it doesn't.) Scaling skinned meshes should be possible (while on latest master, it isn't). You should test this with `testentities_sam.b3d` in place of `gltf_frog.gltf` and vary the `visual_scale`.
output:
Severity: medium
Component: graphics
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: [no squash] Fix handling of skinned meshes for nodes

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: `bevy_text` parley migration

Description: # Objective Minimal-ish `bevy_text` migration from cosmic-text to parley 0.7. ## Solution Internally the `bevy_text::pipeline` module has been completely rewritten. * `shape_text` shapes the text. * `update_text_layout_info` updates the glyph geometry for rendering and handles strikethrough and underline. The fields of `TextNodeFlags` have been renamed: * `needs_measure_fn` -> `needs_shaping` * `needs_recompute` -> `needs_relayout` The public builder API is unchanged, but internally `FontFeatures` now keeps a list of parley `FontFeature`s. The `From<&FontFeatures> for cosmic_text::FontFeatures` implementation has been removed. In its place `FontFeatures` now has an `as_slice` method that returns a `&[FontFeature]` slice that can be passed directly to parley. Most of the other APIs and beha
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: `bevy_text` parley migration

Title: Warn, not panic, on invalid fonts

Description: # Objective Fix panics due to invalid legacy fonts that we can't generate glyph images from. Fixes #22475 ## Solution * In `text_system` and `update_text2d_layout`, instead of panicking on `TextError::FailedToGetGlyphImage`, `warn_once` and clear the text layout. * Given an invalid font, Cosmic Text returns an invalid text layout with infinite text bounds. If Cosmic Text returns non-finite bounds, return a zero size from the `buffer_dimensions` function. * Added a `get_face_details` method to `CosmicFontSystem` to provide better info for the warning messages. `buffer_dimensions` probably should be reworked to return a `Result`, with the text systems emitting a warning on invalid layout bounds. Not so important though, left for a follow up. ## Testing The `system_fonts` example should no lo

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: Fix drag-resizing `Control` with non-zero `pivot_offset_ratio`

Description: Fixes #115977. In case of non-zero `pivot_offset_ratio` changing Control's `size` affects its transform, and hence it needs to be accounted for when setting the `position`. Specifically in `Control::_edit_set_rect` we're getting a new desired local rect `p_edit_rect`. Setting `size = p_edit_rect.size` is fine, as Control's `size` is local. On the other hand Control's `position` is in the parent space / coordinate system, and hence needs to account for the possible internal transform change caused by the `size` change. ``` # For Control: combined_pivot == pivot_offset + pivot_offset_ratio * size _get_internal_transform() == T(combined_pivot) * R(rotation) * S(scale) * T(-combined_pivot) // TRS are translation/rotation/scale transformations get_transform() == T(position) * _get_internal_tran
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Fix drag-resizing `Control` with non-zero `pivot_offset_ratio`

Title: Formspec: change tabs with ctrl+tab

Description: This PR adds the ability to switch to the next/previous tab using <kbd>ctrl</kbd>(+<kbd>shift</kbd>) +<kbd>tab</kbd>. ##### Note: I have used AI during development. - Goal of the PR Make it easier/quicker to go to the next/previous tab using keyboard controls. - How does the PR work? It modifies the `GUIFormSpecMenu`'s `OnEvent` method to cycle through tabs using the above mentioned keyboard shortcut. There are also a few event handling refinements: * Updated `GUIFormSpecMenu`'s `preprocessEvent` method to prevent `Ctrl+Tab` and `Return` keys from being incorrectly consumed by child elements like checkboxes, tables, and list boxes. * Modified `GUITable` to pass key events with the `Control` modifier to its parent, ensuring consistent event propagation. * Adjusted `GUITable`'s `OnEvent` met

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: Lua - C++ type conversion strictness

Description: ### Problem Luanti API bindings often behave javascript-esque (just do something unexpected, aka "weakly typed") when you feed them the wrong types. They should behave lua-esque (aka "strongly typed") and throw errors instead. This also varies depending on the API method and is hardly documented. The end result is that modders simply can't rely on the engine doing something reasonable if they make a mistake. This also causes problems for us: The more lax code we have, the more modders come to rely on it and it becomes hard to make meaningful changes. See for example #16158. ### Solution I think we should strictly map primitive types like this, rejecting everything else with an error: * `std::optional<T>` <-> luatype(T) | none | nil * bool <-> boolean * std::string <-> string (not exactly,
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Lua - C++ type conversion strictness

Title: 0.18.0-rc.1 Aabb3d::new is being passed the wrong arguments

Description: ## Bevy version and features 0.18.0-rc.1 ## What you did Attempt to create a custom mesh asset whose coordinates are all negative ## What went wrong Aabb3d initializers panics at the assert on line 68. ## Additional information The reason why is it is being called incorrectly. Line 2168 of bevy_mesh/mesh.rs. The initializer wants center and half extents. But mesh.rs passes min and max. So for a mesh where all coords are negative, the max coord would also be negative. This is incorrectly passed as being the half extents, and the assertion that the half extents are greater than zero fails.

output:

Title: Resolve multisampled prepass textures

Description: # Objective Fixes #22830, fixes #22831 ## Solution `DepthPrepass` texture is changed to `R32Float` which is resolved with new `ResolvePlugin` in `prepass_depth_resolve` pass. Bonus: WebGPU doesn't support filterable depth textures, but float32-filterable is generally supported. WebGL2 should also support resolved depth prepass. Multisampled `NormalPrepass` and `MotionVectorPrepass` textures are transient and are resolved during prepass. ## Testing `shader_prepass` example can toggle MSAA. DLSS and solari are likely broken due to changed depth prepass texture format.
output:

Summary: Resolve multisampled prepass textures

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: Make camera main texture size viewport-sized and configurable

Description: # Objective Closes #21530. Fixes #22492. Fixes #17375. ## Solution Currently, Bevy's camera main texture size is always set to the physical target size (i.e., the screen size). The main render pass sets viewport to the camera's physical viewport to render region onto camera main texture. Finally in upscaling, the viewport region of camera main texture blits to the swap chain with scissor rect. In my view this has some drawbacks: - It complicates configurable main texture size, as you need to render viewport to a scaled target-sized main texture. - The area outside the viewport is unused, wasting memory. Furthermore, in the main pass we must remember to `set_viewport` for correct rendering. Generally post-processing should also set viewport (thought I only saw `Bloom` does). Otherwise the e
output:
Severity: medium
Component: gameplay
Reproducibility: always
Summary: Make camera main texture size viewport-sized and configurable

Title: [Proposal] Unified UI Layout & Modular Touch Input Element for Cross-Platform Luanti

Description: ### Summary This single-issue proposal outlines a complete overhaul of Luanti’s UI and input system by: 1. Defining two parent containers—**HUD** and **Window**—for all in-game and menu interfaces 2. Introducing one versatile child element—**Thumbstick**—that handles every touch or click interaction (joystick, button press, slider, dial, gesture, etc.) This isn’t just “for mobile.” It’s a **cross-platform UI expansion** that works on PC, touchscreen hybrids, Android/Touchscreen devices and beyond. Touchscreens benefit most today, but the same logic and structure apply everywhere. --- ### Problem - **Fragmented, hardcoded controls**: Joystick, buttons, menus are locked behind engine code with no modular API (e.g. no Lua function to create or configure UI parents or children at runtime) - **

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: fix node not found error in process_simplify_path

Description: - Fix: #98052. When developing a multiplayer game, "Node not found" error occurs sometimes and the synchronizer stops working. This is because the authority peer sends the `NETWORK_COMMAND_SIMPLIFY_PATH` only once (per synchronizer) to other peers — whose corresponding nodes may not yet exist at that time — meaning those peers miss the only opportunity to execute `process_simplify_path` successfully. This PR fixes this by having the authority peer send the `NETWORK_COMMAND_SIMPLIFY_PATH` to other peers continuously until the latter echo the `NETWORK_COMMAND_CONFIRM_PATH`.
output:
Severity: medium
Component: gameplay
Reproducibility: rare
Summary: fix node not found error in process_simplify_path

Title: `DirectionalNavigationMap` no longer caches `AutoDirectionalNavigation` node connections

Description: # Objective - Fixes #21949 ## Solution At the suggestion of @viridia and affirmed by @ickshonpe on Discord, the directional navigation map should no longer contain any `AutoDirectionalNavigation` node connections. This PR: - Removes the system that inserts those types of connections into the map and places the burden of the map’s management fully onto the developer. The directional navigation map is now only used to specify **manual** edges. - Adds a brute force search among `AutoDirectionalNavigation` nodes within the `navigate` function of the `DirectionalNavigation` system parameter. `navigate` will prefer to find a destination within the map of manual edges first before conducting the brute force search. ## Testing - Did you test these changes? If so, how? There are two relevant exampl

Title: `AreaStore` uses too small 16-bit integer types

Description: Reported by repetitivestrain on IRC. Two instances of this: > New bug: AreaStores with more than 65536 values cannot be serialized completely and > repetitivestrain: another bug, coordinates provided to AreaStore queries are truncated into shorts with wraparound arithmetic Neither of these limitations is documented, nor is there a good reason for them to exist at all. The former should probably be fixed via a new serialization version. If the AreaStore is small enough, we can use the old version for compatibility, otherwise we must use the new one. The latter should be alleviated by (1) rounding appropriately and (2) clamping instead of wrapping around. --- From a Lua API user perspective, ideally we should even go one step further, and just use doubles for coordinates everywhere throughou

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: Problems with `Font`s as `Asset`s

Description: ## The problems with `Font`s as `Asset`s 1. When a `Font`’s asset handles are dropped, the font data isn’t deleted because Cosmic Text clones the `Arc` holding the font data and stores it in its `FontDb`. Once a font is added to the database, it can’t be removed. The only way to remove fonts is to create a new `FontDb` instance without the font you want to remove. Creating a new database changes all font `ID`s, which requires regenerating all font atlases, text data, and layouts. This is all very expensive and probably not something that should happen automatically. 2. If a font handle is dropped and its font asset is unloaded, its old `FontDb` entry isn't overwritten. Instead, if you reload the same font again later, a new entry for the font data is added to cosmic text's `FontDb`, alongs
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: rare
Summary: Problems with `Font`s as `Asset`s

Title: `AsBindGroup` derive rejects valid `Depth` + `Filtering` sampler combination

Description: ## Bevy version and features 0.18 ## What you did When using `AsBindGroup` derive: ```rust #[derive(AsBindGroup)] struct MyMaterial { #[texture(0, sample_type = "depth")] #[sampler(1)] depth_texture: Handle<Image>, } ``` ## What went wrong The bind group construction fails at runtime: ``` Bind group construction failed: At binding index 1, the provided image sampler `Depth` does not match the required sampler type(s) `[Float { filterable: true }]`. ``` This happens because `AsBindGroup`'s generated code determines the sampler type from the image's texture format. For depth formats, `TextureFormat::sample_type()` returns `TextureSampleType::Depth`, and the validation rejects it against the expected `Float { filterable: true }`. Using `sampler_type = "comparison"` avoids the validation error
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: Android: Fix `Bad file descriptor` in SAF/MediaStore in long term access

Description: This PR fixes `Bad file descriptor` issue when files are kept open for long periods on Android. Added parcelFileDescriptor as a class property to a class property in SAFData and MediaStoreData, to provide a strong reference to ensure garbage collector doesn't trigger it's finalizer. Overrides close() for these to explicitly release the ParcelFileDescriptor to prevent resource leaks. However, I'd emphasize that it is still recommended to open, read/write, and close files as needed rather than keeping them open indefinitely. Fixes: https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/115567
output:
Severity: medium
Component: performance
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Android: Fix `Bad file descriptor` in SAF/MediaStore in long term access

input:
Title: Fix GDExtension breakage in removed `AudioEffectSpectrumAnalyzer::get_tap_back_pos`

Description: Pull request https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/114355 accidentally breaks GDExtension API. The getter `AudioEffectSpectrumAnalyzer::get_tap_back_pos` was originally const-qualified, but the compat method wasn't. Since const-qualification is taken into account when computing a function hash, this means that the compat method no longer matches the original one, causing breakage.
output:
Severity: high
Component: audio
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Fix GDExtension breakage in removed `AudioEffectSpectrumAnalyzer::get_tap_back_pos`

Nope. - Does this relate to a goal in [the roadmap](https://github.com/luanti-org/luanti/blob/master/doc/direction.md)? No. - If not a bug fix, why is this PR needed? What usecases does it solve? instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: Make builtin check for expected engine version

Description: ### Problem Builtin and the engine need to be kept in sync. When they aren't, you get cryptic errors. Such as this one: #16317, or main menu errors. ### Solutions Have some sort of version check in builtin. (Or conversely: Declare the builtin version in builtin and have the C++ check that against the C++ version.) I'm not yet sure how to best do this without introducing another release chore. We can probably shove it into `bump_version`? ### Alternatives Try to find out how they get out-of-sync, and try to patch that; but often this may be out of our control (e.g. a package being poorly maintained) ### Additional context Main menu instance of this: #16117
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Make builtin check for expected engine version
